facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 99 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 99 of 1970. Appeal by Special Leave

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from Judgment and Order dated 28th January 1970 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1888 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 28th January 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1888 of 1967.

facts.text: Three persons Mahendra Singh, Lakhan Singh and appellant Sukh Ram tried for murder of Chunni Lal under s.302 read with s.34 IPC by Sessions Judge Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: Three persons, Mahendra Singh, Lakhan Singh and the appellant Sukh Ram, were tried for the murder of one Chunni Lal under s. 302 read with s. 34. I. P. C.

facts.text: Sessions Judge Aligarh acquitted Mahendra Singh.

anchor.surface_text: by the Sessions Judge, Aligarh. The Sessions Judge acquitted Mahendra Singh, and convicted and sentenced

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted and sentenced Lakhan Singh and Sukh Ram to imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge acquitted Mahendra Singh, and convicted and sentenced the remaining two to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court on appeal acquitted Lakhan Singh and affirmed conviction and sentence of appellant Sukh Ram.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court of Allahabad acquitted Lakhan Singh and affirmed the conviction and sentence of the appellant.

facts.text: Chunni Lal had a tea stall near the Bus Stand in Sasni.

anchor.surface_text: Hence this appeal. The deceased Chunni Lal has a tea stall near the Bus Stand in Sasni.

facts.text: Chunni Lal was shot dead on 9-3-1967 at about 10-30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: He was shot dead on 9-3-1967 at about 10-30 p.m. The First Information Report of the incident

facts.text: First Information Report lodged by Sunder Lal, relation of deceased.

anchor.surface_text: The First Information Report of the incident was lodged by Sunder Lal, a relation of the deceased.

facts.text: Prosecution examined Sunder Lal, Radhey Shyam, Puran Mal and Devi Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution examined Sunder Lal, Radhey Shyam, Puran Mal and Devi Prasad to prove its case against the aforesaid accused.

facts.text: Sessions Judge believed all witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge believed all the witnesses.

facts.text: High Court Judges S. D. Khare and Jagmohan Lal Sinha analyzed evidence and held remaining evidence proves guilt of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In a careful and sifting analysis of the entire evidence, the learned Judges of the High Court  S. D. Khare and Jagmohan Lal Sinha JJ.  have winnowed

facts.text: Supreme Court read entire evidence and satisfied that High Court rightly found appellant guilty of murder of Chunni Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant could not point out any infirmity in their opinion. We have read the entire evidence, and we are satisfied

facts.text: Charge framed by Sessions Judge against Sukh Ram s/o Hari Ram, Lakhan Singh s/o Biri Singh, Mahendra Singh s/o Gulab Chand.

anchor.surface_text: The charge framed by the Sessions Judge reads I Sessions Judge, Aligarh, hereby charge you Sukh Ram S o Hari Ram, Lakhan Singh s o Biri Singh and Mahenara Singh

facts.text: Charge: on 9th March 1967 at 10.30 pm in Sasni near bus stand at shop of Chunni Lal, in furtherance of common intention to murder, committed murder by one firing pistol.

anchor.surface_text: That you on the 9th day of March, 1967, at about 10.30 p.m. in the town of Sasni near the bus stand at the- shop of Chunni Lal in furtherance of your common intention

facts.text: Sessions Court found direct evidence proves Sukh Ram along with two other companions went to Chunni Lal's shop and one companion fired pistol while closing shop.

facts.text: High Court acquitted Lakhan Singh because unsafe to rely on sole testimony of Kunwarji for identification.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court acquitted Lakhan Singh because it thought it unsafe to rely on the sole testimony of Kunwarji in regard to Lakhan Singhs identification.

facts.text: High Court and Supreme Court certain there were three culprits, appellant being one.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges of the High Court were certain, and we are in agreement with their view, that there were three culprits, appellant being one of those three.

facts.text: High Court opinion: Sukh Ram amongst three assailants, pistol fired in furtherance of common intention of all three.

arguments.claim: In Dalip Singh, acquittal proper as FIR named only acquitted and convicted, no others suggested.

holdings.text: We have read the entire evidence, and we are satisfied that they have rightly found the appellant guilty of the murder of Chunni Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant could not point out any infirmity in their opinion. We have read the entire evidence, and we are satisfied that they have rightly found the appellantguilty of the murder of Chunni Lal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court independently reviewed entire evidence after noting counsel could not identify infirmities in High Court's analysis, which had sifted and winnowed objectionable evidence.

holdings.text: no prejudice can be said to have been caused to the appellant by reason of his conviction under section 302 read with section 34, Penal Code, even though the two other accused specifically named in the charge have been acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: But in view of the unambiguous evidence tendered by the prosecution in the Sessions Court, no prejudice can be said to have been caused to the appellant by reason of his conviction under section 302 read with section 34, Penal Code, even though the two other accused specifically named in the charge have been acquitted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unambiguous prosecution evidence showed murder by appellant and two others; appellant's defense cross-examination reflected awareness of allegations; Sessions Judge examined under s.342 CrPC on participation with companions.

holdings.text: It is fully established that Sukh Ram was amongst the three assailants of Chunni Lal and that the pistol was fired at Chunni Lal in furtherance of the common intention of all the three assailants.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that it is fully established that Sukh Ram was amongst the three assailants of Chunni Lal and that the pistol was fired at Chunni Lal in furtherance of the common intention of all the three assailants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sessions Court found direct evidence proves beyond reasonable doubt participation with two companions and firing; High Court agreed after acquitting one on identification; Supreme Court in agreement.

holdings.text: there were three culprits, appellant being one of those three.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges of the High Court were certain, and we are in agreement with their view, that there were three culprits, appellant being one of those three.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court certain despite acquitting Lakhan on weak identification; Supreme Court agrees based on evidence review.

holdings.text: notwithstanding the charge, the acquittal of Mahendra Singh and Lakhan Singh raises no bar to the conviction of the appellant under s. 302 read with s. 34.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that notwithstanding the charge, the acquittal of Mahendra Singh and Lakhan Singh raises no bar to the conviction of the appellant under s. 302 read with s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence proved common intention with two companions despite charge naming specific three; distinguished precedents like Dalip Singh, Mohan Singh where no evidence of others; followed Bharwad Nepa Dana, Kartar Singh allowing unnamed where evidence supports; no prejudice.

holdings.text: A possible prejudice to the accused, on a reasonable view of the course the trial has taken, is the true touch-stone of such matters.

anchor.surface_text: A possible prejudice to the accused, on a reasonable view of the course the trial has taken, is the true touch- stone of such matters and we have warned ourselves of that danger before coming to the conclusion that the High Court is right in the view it has taken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court applied this test and found no prejudice after considering evidence, procedure, and precedents.

precedents.citation: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 1

precedents.case_name: Dalip Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Acquittal of some named co-accused in FIR and charge precludes conviction of remaining under s.302/149 IPC where no other persons mentioned and no mistaken identity issue
precedents.cited_holding: If witnesses certain of some but uncertain of others among named, conviction of certain ones proper only if possibility of more; here all named, no others suggested, so acquittal

precedents.citation: Bharwad Nepa Dana v. State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Bharwad Nepa Dana v. State of Bombay 1

precedents.case_name: Bharwad Nepa Dana v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Conviction under s.302/149 possible with unidentified persons forming unlawful assembly if evidence supports more than required number participating
precedents.cited_holding: Nothing in law prevents finding unlawful assembly of convicted persons plus unidentified persons exceeding five

precedents.citation: Kartar Singh v. State of Punjab 2

anchor.surface_text: Kartar Singh v. State of Punjab  2

precedents.case_name: Kartar Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Conviction under s.302/149 upheld if evidence shows more than required number participated even if identities of some not proved, acquittal of named doesn't preclude if possibility of others
precedents.cited_holding: Only when number definite, all named, and proved participants less than five without possibility of others, conviction not possible

precedents.citation: Mohan Singh v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Mohan Singh v. State of Punjab 1

precedents.case_name: Mohan Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Where prosecution case specifies exact named persons only as assembly, acquittal of some reduces number below requisite for s.149
precedents.cited_holding: As soon as two of five named acquitted, assembly deemed three, not unlawful

precedents.citation: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra 1

anchor.surface_text: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra 1

precedents.case_name: Krishna Govind Patil v State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: Conviction under s.302/34 not sustainable after acquittal of all other named co-accused where no evidence of any other persons involved

It is, therefore, clear that notwithstanding the charge, the acquittal of Mahendra Singh and Lakhan Singh raises numberbar to the companyviction of the appellant under s. 302 read with s.
